title: Maritime Expressions
description: Seafaring phrases used in everyday English

questions.question: What does the expression 'learning the ropes' originally refer to?
options: Learning to tie knots in school
A new sailor learning to handle the ship's rigging
Training horses with rope halters
Learning to climb mountains

questions.question: Where does the phrase 'three sheets to the wind' come from?
options: Hanging laundry on a clothesline
Sailing terminology for a ship out of control when its sails are loose
A kite-flying competition
Windmill operation

questions.question: What does 'batten down the hatches' originally mean?
options: Close the windows of a house
Secure a ship's hatch covers with strips of wood before a storm
Lock the doors of a fortress
Tie down cargo on a wagon

questions.question: What is the nautical origin of 'taken aback'?
options: Being pushed backward by a wave
When wind suddenly blows sails flat against the mast, stopping the ship
Falling overboard unexpectedly
Running aground on a sandbar

questions.question: What does 'give a wide berth' mean in sailing?
options: Offer a large cabin to an important passenger
Keep a safe distance from another ship or obstacle
Build a wider dock for larger ships
Lower the anchor in deep water

questions.question: Where does the phrase 'by and large' come from?
options: Measuring cargo containers
Sailing terms meaning 'by the wind' and 'with the wind large (behind)'
The size of a ship's flag
Comparing large and small vessels

questions.question: What does 'the bitter end' refer to in sailing?
options: The taste of sea salt
The last part of a rope or chain secured to the ship
A sailor's final voyage
The stern of the ship

questions.question: What is the origin of the phrase 'plain sailing'?
options: Sailing without any decorative flags
Navigating on a flat chart with simple, straightforward conditions
A ship with no cargo
Sailing in a straight line

questions.question: What does 'run aground' mean in nautical terms?
options: Sail very fast
When a ship's hull hits the seabed in shallow water
Abandon ship and swim to shore
Dock the ship in port

questions.question: Where does the expression 'in the doldrums' come from?
options: A type of seasickness
A calm area near the equator where ships could be stranded without wind
A dark, cold region of the ocean
An underwater cave system

questions.question: What does 'showing your true colors' originally mean at sea?
options: Painting the ship's hull
Revealing a ship's actual national flag after flying a false one
Wearing a colorful uniform
Displaying signal flags for identification

questions.question: What is the nautical meaning of 'keelhauling'?
options: Cleaning barnacles from the ship
A severe punishment of dragging someone under the ship's keel
Turning the ship around
Repairing a damaged hull

questions.question: What does 'all hands on deck' originally mean?
options: Everyone must wash their hands
Every crew member must come to the main deck, usually for an emergency
A card game played by sailors
Inspecting the ship before departure

questions.question: Where does the phrase 'cut and run' come from in sailing?
options: Cutting fish while running along the deck
Cutting the anchor cable to make a quick escape
Trimming the sails while sailing fast
Cutting rope to release a lifeboat

questions.question: What does 'between the devil and the deep blue sea' refer to in nautical terms?
options: Choosing between two ports
Being stuck between a dangerous seam on the hull (the 'devil') and the ocean
Navigating between pirates and a storm
Choosing between two captains
